newsitem.title: UK: Scottish nationalists aim to break British power.
newsitem.headline: Scottish nationalists aim to break British power.

text.p: Scottish nationalist leader Alex Salmond said on Friday an independent Scotland could become the economic "tiger" of Europe and called on members to break the power of the British state over their country.
The Scottish National Party (SNP) chief said Scotland would only flourish "when it ruled itself and took part in the counsels of the world".

"Our objective is to break the power of the state of the United Kingdom over the Scottish people," Salmond told the party's last annual conference before a general election that must be called by next May.
He called on Scots "to rise and be a nation again".

The SNP, which espouses purely peaceful, political methods, is in buoyant mood, with opinion poll support boosted to at least 29 percent by a series of Scottish policy gaffes by the opposition Labour Party, the biggest party in Scotland.
The SNP have four members of the British parliament, and will need a big swing to boost that number significantly because of the British "first-past-the-post" voting system.
Salmond said in a statement released before his keynote speech that on current growth levels Ireland would become more porsperous than Britain by the year 2000.
Ireland currently boasts the highest growth rate in the european union of around seven per cent per annum.
"But compared to Scotland, Ireland has next to no resources," Salmond wrote. "They have used their imagination and human resources in order to drive their economy forward.
"With the freedom of independence, Scotland could combine our own talents with the nation's abundant resources, and make Scotland the "tiger economy" of Europe."

Salmond devoted a large part of his speech to the SNP faithful, meeting in the Highland capital Inverness, to knocking his opponents. "You couldn't place a cigarette paper between their policies," he said.

Salmond said the Conservative government in London was responsible for the mishandling of the crisis over mad cow disease, asserting that "the livelihoods of our rural communities have been sacrificed and jeopardised to Tory (Conservative) Party internal politics".

Labour, which has in recent months come up with a series of contradictory statements on a possible Scottish parliament, were no more than "tartan Tories" who could not be trusted with the Scottish constitution.

Salmond based his forecast of Scotland's prospects as a European "tiger" -- a reference to the small but dynamic "tiger economies" of Asia -- on research carried out for the party by the House of Commons library in London.

It said that Irish gross domestic product per head was projected "to have exceeded that of Wales in 1995 and will exceed that of Scotland, and the UK as a whole, by the year 2000", provided Ireland maintained recent high growth rates.
The SNP maintains that an independent Scotland would be the 21st richest country in the world.
